docs.snippet: Mark Zuckerberg of Facebook and Jack Ma of Alibaba discussed the state of the Chinese economy at a forum in Beijing on Saturday.
Though most people under 50 are online, a few choose to remain elusive on Twitter and such, trying to preserve their privacy, sanity — and noteworthiness.

headline.print_headline: Holdouts of the Social Media Age
headline.main: Holdouts of the Social Media Age

docs.abstract: Teddy Wayne Future Tense column notes that there is select minority of young people who deliberately choose to eschew social networking websites in effort to preserve their privacy and sanity.

docs.snippet: Charges of bias at Facebook Trending; a bad week for tech companies; ride-hailing and the cities.

headline.main: Farhad and Mike’s Week in Tech: Facebook’s Take on the News

docs.snippet: With Congress refusing to close a background check loophole that allows felons to buy guns, Facebook will stop users from placing ads to sell guns.

headline.print_headline: Facebook’s Sensible Ban on Gun Ads
headline.main: Facebook’s Sensible Ban on Gun Ads

docs.abstract: Editorial praises move by Facebook to ban private gun sales on its social networking sites, including Instagram; chastises Congress for its unwillingness to restrict vast and thriving venue for unlicensed gun sales.

docs.snippet: The rising tension between borderless technology and countries that cling to their cultural identities has echoes in disruptive technology of the past.

headline.main: American Tech Giants vs. the Nation-State

docs.snippet: European efforts to rein in the largest American tech companies are only a taste of what countries like Brazil, India and China are likely to do.

headline.print_headline: Global Battle Lines Form as U.S. Technology Companies Expand
headline.main: Why the World Is Drawing Battle Lines Against American Tech Giants

docs.abstract: Farhad Manjoo State of the Art column observes that European Commission's efforts to reign in power of Silicon Valley companies like Apple and Google is just beginning of what will become global freak-out over American tech industry's growing powers; suggests worldwide resistance is due in part to companies' espousal of American values, and fact that they could become so entrenched in societies that they will be difficult to uproot.

docs.snippet: The F.B.I. won’t say what it found on the San Bernardino gunman’s iPhone, and WhatsApp says it has encrypted all communications, as the push-pull over digital privacy continues.

headline.main: F.B.I. May Have Put Down Sword, but Privacy Debate Goes On

docs.snippet: These automated software critters are growing in popularity, especially now that they’re doing more than pretending to be a human in a call center.

headline.main: Bots are Back, and They Might Even Be Welcome

docs.snippet: The company said a code change was responsible for the problems, but declined to say how many users were affected.

headline.print_headline: Coding Update Leads to Worldwide Disruptions for Twitter

docs.abstract: Twitter blames code change for global disruption in its service and says it has reversed change and fixed issue.

docs.snippet: The Internet messaging service, owned by Facebook, said it would phase out fees to use the service and experiment with charging companies to talk directly to its almost one billion users worldwide.

headline.print_headline: Whatsapp Messaging Service Will Drop Annual 99-Cent Fee
headline.main: WhatsApp, the Internet Messenger, to Become Free

docs.abstract: The Internet messaging service, owned by Facebook, said it would phase out fees to use the service and experiment with charging companies to talk directly to its almost one billion users worldwide.
